text: Why are all Mathas decks based on curses?
Because <@U4BFDSLKT> is a monster
Because if you're gonna use a terrible, near unplayable commander you may as well do so using a terrible, near unplayable archetype
Mathas is very much a commander designed by someone who didn't understand EDH, at all.
I have subsisted on near-unplayable commanders and archetypes for many an age, sir!
But you're very correct.

I like bad stuff but Mathas is bad in a different way in that he doesn't work the way the designers intended because it very much seems like he was designed by someone who doesn't understand threat or resource advantage
It doesnt have the distracting effect Xantcha has of making another player the target.

They seemed to think his bounty counter would generate political things or cause people to want to take out the bountied creature, and maybe if does if you're playing with the worst players in the world, but if you're playing with anyone paying attention you pretty quickly realize that outside 1v1 bounties make you LESS likely to remove the thing
I'll cut and paste this from a previous Mathas conversation:

The theory is you put a bounty counter on a thing to encourage it's removal, presumably something scary enough to want it gone. People will be encouraged to then remove that target as they'll then get a card.
Except everyone gets a card except the person who lost the dude. So you use your spell (that can't be an exile or tuck which is a lot of great spells) and draw a card, and two people you need to eventually kill get a card. You're card neutral in the exchange as well as down mana, and two people are up cards. That's not good math.
So take it to the next step. The juiciest target for the bounty counter is probably going to be the thing people just generally want gone regardless, say an Elesh Norn. They'd probably remove it if they could anyway, or will at the first chance. By slapping a bounty on it all do you is make the person doing the eventual removal want to remove it LESS. They went from planning to Dreadbore that Norn to get it off the field to looking at Dreadbore'ing the Norn and helping people they have to kill later on by giving them cards. By putting the bounty on Norn you've made it a less attractive target, the opposite of the theoretical intent of Mathis.

Okay, so you don't slap it on Norn since you figure that'll get destroyed anyway, but instead put it on the third scariest thing in play hoping to encourage that to get removed. What does that accomplish? If the person changes their mind to not Dreadbore Norn to get the draw, that's not ideal because Norn lives, and you still have the problem of you drawing one card and your enemies drawing two.
So ideally then the Dreadbore still happens on Norn, and instead a third person uses their Go for the Throat on the bountied target. So you baited out a removal, removed a creature, and gotten a draw. Yeah, you've given up two other draws too, but maybe that's a fine trade, right? If someone who is holding a Go for the Throat is willing to give their enemies cards and waste a removal spell on a third-teir threat just for a lone card to hand do you really need to do anything that complicated to beat them? They're probably just gonna wind up choking on their own dice anyway.
To throw a monkey wrench into things, if bounty tokens disincentivize destruction, putting targets on things you *don’t* want killed is also a potential application
Just a musing

Sure, but then you're running a commander who only brings to the table maybe making opponent's creatures you don't want gone slightly less attractive to kill. That's still bad. It's not Lady of the Mountain bad, but by any modern commander design that's pretty terrible.
There's also disincentivising the card draw and/or life gain for others. But what are you cutting for [[Tainted Remedy]]?

attachments.fallback: Tainted Remedy {2}{B} // Enchantment // If an opponent would gain life, that player loses that much life instead.
attachments.text:
Enchantment
If an opponent would gain life, that player loses that much life instead.
_"Drink this, brother. It will bring you rest."—Liliana Vess_
attachments.title: Tainted Remedy {2}{B}

text: That said, Mathas gets better 1v1, so if you're in a meta where people get bumped off at different times and you don't care about using him until that point then he's probably still bad but not as bad.
Yeah, if you wanna build around punishing opponents for gaining life he's maybe a way to do it
I feel like we all have one commander that gets under our skin like that. Dana hates Mathas, I hate Ezuri, Henry hates everything...
Lol, yeah Mathas tilts me
Dana is a cEDH player in disguise.
I'm learning so much about what to not do
And Matt is a casual player in disguise
The only reason he’s here is to refine his manifesto and use our logic against us
I've seen a [[Bartel Runeaxe]] deck before, and he's terrible

text: I know I’m a casual when it comes to edh. Never denied that one
But I think the difference is if you're playing Bartel you know he's terrible, so it doesn't bug me. I think most Mathas players don't get it, and for some reason that's what tilts me.
Spealing of bad generals, I just built a Dromar deck.
I saw a cool Dromar deck years ago that had some wierd hook, but damned if I can remember what it was
"I name black...oh that bounces Dromar...sh*t!"
lol yeah
The deck uses the bounce to its advantage. Should be in a future article for the site.
I guarentee there's someone who has built that deck, gotten to the shop all excited, swung in a game, and only then realized 3 of 5 choices bounce his commander and probalby a few of his creatuers
I thought about [[Tidal Visionary]] to fix him, but kept him out in the end.

text: I don’t know if there’s any fixing that...
At that point, is all the effort worth the payoff?
If it's fun, sure
Ha, says the guy who just winded himself about mathas
Focusing on bounce lets me play some fun cards like [[Stormfromt Riders]] and [[Azorius Aethermage]]. Either Merieke or Dromar as commander seemed to best fit this theme.
